title: Memorial where Australian backpacker Lucas Fowler and US girlfriend Cynna Deese were murdered
text:
Two 'guardian angel' truck drivers have come together to keep the memory alive of two backpackers who were murdered.

Temperatures as low as -50C could reach the abandoned highway where lovers Australian Lucas Fowler, 23, and his American girlfriend Chynna Deese, 24, were horrifically murdered.

Ed Grennan and John Van Vyfeyken have built a shelter for the memorial to ensure no damage is done to the shrine, and to show the families that they are safe.

Australian Lucas Fowler (right) and his American girlfriend Chynna Deese (left) were horrifically murdered by Kam McLeod and Bryer Schmegelsky

Ed Grennan and John Van Vyfeyken have built a shelter for the memorial to ensure no damage is done to the shrine

'It is for the families, it is helping them cope,' Mr Van Vyfeyken told Nine News.

'The memorial is there to keep the memory of this couple alive.

'Hopefully it helps the families … knowing we are all keeping Lucas and Chynna in our thoughts and prayers.'

The memorial is covered with flowers, the Australia and US flag, as well as large wooden crosses with Lucas and Chynna's name, cans of beer, cigars, dolls, notes and cards.

The loved up pair were found dead on July 15 after their van broke down on the Alaska Highway, British Columbia.

The memorial is covered with flowers, the Australia and US flag, as well as large wooden crosses with Lucas and Chynna's name, cans of beer, cigars, dolls, notes and cards

Wooden crosses with Lucas and Chynna's names on them were put on the shrine (pictured)

Kam McLeod, 18, and Bryer Schmegelsky, 19, went on a murder rampage in northern British Columbia in July, first shooting dead Mr Fowler then Ms Deese, 24, with SKS semi-automatic rifles.

The couple's van had broken down and RCMP assistant commissioner Kevin Hackett said McLeod and Schmegelsky targeted them for 'unknown reasons'.

McLeod and Schmegelsky reportedly left their hometown of Port Alberni, British Columbia, on July 12 after telling family members they were going to search for work in Whitehorse, Yukon.

The teenage killers decided to end their lives after they became stranded in an area near a fast-moving river and thick bushland west of Hudson Bay.
